pull.title: torcontrol: Remove libevent usage
pull.body:
This is part of the effort to remove the libevent dependency from our code base: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/31194

There is a dependency on #32061 but it only really needs one commit which is cherry-picked here in first position (add `LineReader`). I hope that a first chunk of that PR can be sliced off and reviewed independently so this PR here is not blocked by it.

The current approach tries to reuse existing code and follows roughly similar design decisions. It replaces the libevent-based async I/O with blocking I/O utilizing the existing `Sock` and `CThreadInterrupt`. The controller runs in a dedicated thread.

There are some optional code modernizations thrown in made along the way (namings, constexpr etc.). These are not strictly necessary but make the end result with the new code more consistent.

events.body: The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers. ### Code Coverage & Benchmarks For details see: https://corecheck.dev/bitcoin/bitcoin/pulls/34158. ### Reviews See [the guideline](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#code-review) for information on the review process. | Type | Reviewers | | ---- | --------- | | Concept ACK | [sedited](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/34158#issuecomment-3694015450), [pinheadmz](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/34158#issuecomment-3694017377), [pablomartin4btc](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/34158#issuecomment-3694074809), [waketraindev](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/34158#issuecomment-3694830686), [janb84](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/34158#pullrequestreview-3614742906) | If your review is incorrectly listed, please copy-paste <!--meta-tag:bot-skip--> into the comment that the bot should ignore. ### Conflicts Reviewers, this pull request conflicts with the following ones: * [#32061](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/32061) (Replace libevent with our own HTTP and socket-handling implementation by pinheadmz) If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Ideally, start with the one that should be merged first.

concept ACK
Quick review on github - where are you using LineReader?

<details><summary>Hints</summary>

Try to run the tests locally, according to the documentation. However, a CI failure may still

* Possibly due to a silent merge conflict (the changes in this pull request being

* A sanitizer issue, which can only be found by compiling with the sanitizer and running the

* An intermittent issue.

Leave a comment here, if you need help tracking down a confusing failure.

> where are you using LineReader?

Heh, I did quite a bit of moving around after I got things working and seems like I picked from the branch where i didn't use it instead of the one where I did at the end. Pushed the right code for it now, using it in `ProcessBuffer`.

Will work on fixing the fuzz test which I completely missed ðŸ™ƒ That's what's failing the CI.
Concept ACK There's some uncovered new code in the coverage report, https://corecheck.dev/bitcoin/bitcoin/pulls/34158 And some Sonarcloud warnings to check out.

Concept ACK 8d6f1b02f5868d918bb72059eac3afb881ccafe3

PR removes LibEvent usages from TorControl and cleans/modernizes the code a bit where touched.

code review, build and test. I do not have sufficient exp. to say something about the fuzz improvement commit. Small NIT found while doing the code review.

<!--85328a0da195eb286784d51f73fa0af9-->

<sub>Task `lint`: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/actions/runs/20560088214/job/59049502835</sub>
<sub>LLM reason (âœ¨ experimental): Python linting failed: an f-string had no placeholders (ruff warning F541) in test/functional/feature_torcontrol.py.</sub>

<details><summary>Hints</summary>

Try to run the tests locally, according to the documentation. However, a CI failure may still

* Possibly due to a silent merge conflict (the changes in this pull request being

* A sanitizer issue, which can only be found by compiling with the sanitizer and running the

* An intermittent issue.

Leave a comment here, if you need help tracking down a confusing failure.

Addressed feedback.

> There's some uncovered new code in the coverage report, https://corecheck.dev/bitcoin/bitcoin/pulls/34158

The old code was largely uncovered as well but I have looked into it and added a simple functional test that provides some basic end-to-end coverage. I thought about unit tests too but I am not sure they provide much value aside from the functional and fuzz tests. But happy to be convinced otherwise if there are ideas for what they should cover.

> And some Sonarcloud warnings to check out.

I don't know what that is and the screenshot doesn't allow me to see which lines are meant by the comment. Happy to look into them if you can transfer the comments matching to the correct lines here somehow.

> I don't know what that is and the screenshot doesn't allow me to see which lines are meant by the comment. Happy to look into them if you can transfer the comments matching to the correct lines here somehow. You can see the warnings on https://corecheck.dev/bitcoin/bitcoin/pulls/34158 scroll down the page, above benchmarks, below uncovered included code You can click them individually to open in SonarCloud. For example: * Replace "reinterpret_cast" with a safer operation. "reinterpret_cast" should not be used https://github.com/isocpp/CppCoreGuidelines/blob/e49158a/CppCoreGuidelines.md#Res-casts

author Matthew Zipkin <pinheadmz@gmail.com> 1727464937 -0400
committer Fabian Jahr <fjahr@protonmail.com> 1767200723 +0100

string: add LineReader

This is a helper struct to parse HTTP messages from data in buffers
from sockets. HTTP messages begin with headers which are
CRLF-terminated lines (\n or \r\n) followed by an arbitrary amount of
body data. Whitespace is trimmed from the field lines but not the body.

https://httpwg.org/specs/rfc9110.html#rfc.section.5

events.message: test: Add simple functional test for torcontrol

events.body:
> You can see the warnings on https://corecheck.dev/bitcoin/bitcoin/pulls/34158 scroll down the page, above benchmarks, below uncovered included code

TIL, thanks. I addressed the ones that made sense to me.

comments.body:
```suggestion
        m_sock.reset();
```

NIT: I think you can remove the redundant check.  calling `reset()` on  a `std::unique_ptr` is safe even if the pointer is already null
